awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Artificial Gravity Stabilization System for Space Habitats
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project enables an entirely new class of space habitat that will enable humans to live and work in space without endangering their health.  In the near future, improvements in launch capability will radically increase the number of people traveling to space to take advantage of what can only be done in microgravity.  These include researchers studying the next lifesaving medicine, workers manufacturing high-purity semiconductors for the next generation of computers, and tourists wanting to experience the freedom of space and the sight of Earth.  These individuals share a common need: easy access to microgravity to fulfill their purpose of being in space while simultaneously not enduring significant health impacts from microgravity exposure; thus, both microgravity and artificial gravity need to be accessible in the same space habitat.  Development of platforms such as these would help enable an acceleration of in-space R&D, along with supporting higher throughput of in-space experimentation and R&D.  The solution is very large, expandable non-rotating space habitats, with an internal rotating centrifuge large enough for astronauts to live and work in when not needing microgravity.  These centrifuges need an advanced stabilization system because as astronauts move around the centrifuge, the center-of-gravity shifts, which due to the rotation would induce a wobble. 

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to solve the stabilization problem while avoiding flaws of previously proposed approaches and is also applicable to traditional rotating space stations.  The objective of this research is to build representative lab-scale prototypes of the stabilization system and develop a control system model to prove the efficacy of this stabilization system when at full scale. This includes capturing the responsiveness required for the system to stabilize human motion, such as walking, proving redundancy is present, and characterizing the overall impact centrifuge mass distribution has on the stabilization control system.  Further prototypes will demonstrate its ability to package within an expandable habitat module, while additional analysis will quantify the cost benefits of designing a habitat incorporating a large internal centrifuge and stabilization system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Radiant Space Systems Inc. (Radiant) has completed a Phase I SBIR advancing the capability of future in-space research and manufacturing. Radiant is building orbital research platforms enabling both 0g and artificial gravity experiments, and eventually human habitation. Research and manufacturing performed on this space lab can improve the quality semiconductors, pharmaceuticals and organoids. Furthermore, it is the only platform in development to contain both microgravity and artificial gravity, which when implemented on a small scale allows for long-duration of partial gravity research, and when implemented in a human-sized space station, prevents many of the detrimental effects of microgravity on the human body.

 A key innovation Radiant developed during this Phase I SBIR was an artificial gravity stabilization system. Beginning with a theoretical model of the artificial gravity system, Radiant designed a mass-balance system which can stabilize the rotating portion of the orbital research platform. The model was then put into practice, being implemented on a ground prototype. The closed-loop active control system was able to reduce vibrations from the artificial gravity centrifuge and validated the approach to within the success criteria. A stabilization system is essential for any large-scale spinning object in space. In the event of movement of payloads or people, the imbalance could create a wobble in the habitat, and without an active method of stabilizing, this wobble could tear the platform apart.

In addition, Radiant has mathematically derived and demonstrated a novel method of folding and storing an inflatable space habitat hull. This new method reduces the risk of damaging the air bladder material during packing and launch, while leaving more open volume available for an artificial gravity centrifuge and stabilization system. A 2-meter diameter ground prototype was constructed, using flight-accurate materials. The new folding method was successfully implemented, and the model was both inflated to full size, and then stored at a diameter small enough to fit into a payload faring, while still providing room for axial structural components. This hull design can be used on both robotic, unmanned habitats as well as future human-occupied space stations.

The successes of this Phase I project demonstrate that there is technical merit behind these novel concepts. Radiant intends to continue R&D on these technologies, and if successful, will be the backbone of an orbital space lab which helps industries from medicine to semiconductor chips improve the efficacy and quality of their products. It will also be a place for science and rapid R&D, helping to maintain US leadership in space and technology.
